text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits the revised IRM 5.12.1, Federal Tax Liens, Lien Program Overview.

SBSE and W&I collection functions, Centralized Lien Operation, and Appeals
Table of Contents

) The federal tax lien is the basis for the government’s claim against the property of a taxpayer who has a tax-related debt. The lien program and passes the legal and administrative aspects of federal tax liens, including ﬁling of notices of federal tax lien. (

) Purpose: This IRM provides an overview of the lien program, contains ences to where guidance for the lien program can be found, and lists the forms, letters, and other documents used in the lien program. (
) Audience: This IRM is used by IRS personnel working federal tax lien (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy, Small Business/Sell-Employed Division (SBSE) (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy is primarily responsible for overseeing lien program. (

) Primary Stakeholders: SBSE Collection and Wage & Investment (W&I) functions involved with collection issues. Other functions that are affected or have input to, the procedures include Chief Counsel, Appeals, and the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS). (
) Program Goals: To protect the interests of the government when a federal debt exists by providing policy and procedural guidance to IRS personnel is consistent with federal lien law. (

) The Internal Revenue Code (IRC), provides the IRS a powerful tool the government to protect the taxpaying public’s interest in collecting the proper amount of tax revenues. This tool is the federal tax lien. (
) The federal tax lien provided under IRC

, which is sometimes called “statutory lien,” is the basis for the government’s claim against the property, including current and future rights to property, and enables of the tax or tax-related debt of the individual or business. (

) While the federal tax lien protects the government’s interest, a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) is needed for the federal tax lien to compete with certain classes of creditors. When ﬁled, the NFTL puts third parties on of a taxpayer’s outstanding lien. (

) Throughout the life of the federal tax lien, situations may arise involving lien. The resolution to these situations can vary and is guided by the IRC, Treasury Regulations (Regs), IRS policy, and IRM procedures. (
) The authorities for the lien program are found in the following IRC and tion sections: Section Regulation Title §
Lien for taxes
IRC Section Regulation Title 26 USC § 6321 §301.6321-1 Lien for taxes 26 USC § 6322 n/a Period of lien 26 USC § 6323 §§301.6323(a)-1 thru Validity and priority against certain persons 301.6323(j)-1

IRC Section Regulation Title 26 USC § 6320 §301.6320-1 Notice and opportunity for hearing upon ﬁling of notice of lien 26 USC § 6324 §301.6324-1 Special liens for estate and gift taxes 26 USC § 6324A §301.6324A-1 Special lien for estate tax deferred under section 6166 26 USC § 6324B n/a Special lien for additional estate tax attributable to farm, etc., valuation 26 USC § 6325 §301.6325-1 Release of lien or discharge of property 26 USC § 6326 §301.6326-1 Administrative appeal of liens 26 USC § 7425 §§301.7425-1 through Discharge of Liens 301.7425-4 26 USC § 7426 §301.7426-1, Civil actions by persons other than taxpayers §301.7426-2 26 USC § 7432 §301.7432-1 Civil damages for failure to release lien 28 USC § 2410 n/a Actions affecting property on which United States has lien

) The Director, Collection Policy is responsible for overseeing policy and dures regarding the lien program. (
) Employees authorized to make determinations regarding lien actions are re- sponsible for following applicable procedures and policy. (
) Managers are responsible for ensuring that lien actions taken by employees are in accordance with policy and procedures. (

) The Centralized Lien Operation (CLO), which often is informally referred to the “Lien Unit,” has primary responsibility for inputting information to, and cessing lien documents generated by, the Automated Lien System (ALS). (
) Any employee who requests, manually prepares, or approves NFTLs and related documents is responsible for ensuring the request or document is
The IRC and the Regs may be researched online using United States or Electronic Code of Federal Regulations, respectively.
accurate and complete. The requestor/preparer is ultimately responsible to that the NFTL document is ﬁled appropriately. (
) Other roles and responsibilities related to the lien program are shown in
, IRS Organizations Working Lien Issues, and its subsections. (

Content, identiﬁes IRM sections ated with NFTL determinations, ﬁling, withdrawal, maintenance, and is within the speciﬁc IRMs that lien program responsibilities, instructions, procedures are identiﬁed. (
) The Automated Lien System (ALS) electronically stores data regarding and is the data source for reports on NFTL ﬁlings, releases, withdrawals, revocations. (

) Speciﬁc case activity on lien issues may be documented on one of several other systems. • The Integrated Collection System (ICS) is used to control lien-related requests worked by Field Collection and document case work. • The Accounts Management System (AMS) is used by CLO to control withdrawal after release requests and by customer service tives to document general case work. • The Automated Collection System (ACS) is used by ACS employees make NFTL determinations and document case work. • The Automated Insolvency System (AIS) is used by Insolvency employees to document work on bankruptcy cases. • The Automated Offer in Compromise System (AOIC) is used by OIC employees to document case work on OIC requests. (
) The systems described in (
) and the ENTITY Case Management System also generate certain, unique reports related to lien processes to assist in managing assigned inventory. (

Overview
) The form used to provide notice of the lien is Form
(Y)(c), Notice of Federal Tax Lien. The form, when properly annotated, is also used for variations, including amended and special condition NFTLs. Note: Form
(Y)(c) is a computer-generated form through ALS. (The “c” indicates “continuous,” the format once used for printing the document.) Manually prepared templates may show Form
(Y). All versions of the form or templates will transition to show Form
-Y. In this IRM, “Form
(Y)” is used in referring to the form. (
) Throughout this IRM section, information is provided regarding other documents, websites, and job aids related to the lien program. (
) IRM

, Legal Reference Guide for Revenue Officers, Federal Tax provides additional details about lien law such as the types of property to the federal tax lien and the priority of the federal tax lien versus other competing encumbrances. (

) Links to tools and references to assist IRS employees with lien processes also be found on the My SB/SE website. Similar information for taxpayers be found on the Understanding a Federal Tax Lien page on IRS.gov. (

sections. (
) IRC
provides the IRS a powerful tool allowing the Government to the American taxpaying public’s interest in collecting the proper amount of Liens revenues. This tool is the federal tax lien. (

) A federal tax lien is a claim against property, including current and future to property. It represents the tax or tax-related debt of an individual or business. Because the lien arises by operation of law, it is sometimes the “statutory lien” or “assessment lien.” Throughout this IRM Chapter, it referred to as the statutory lien or simply “lien.” (

) While the Service makes the taxpayer aware of the existence of the lien, it does not make the lien’s existence public until a notice of the lien has ﬁled. The IRS puts third parties on notice of a taxpayer’s outstanding lien ﬁling a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) in the appropriate, local office. (

) There are some common misunderstandings among external, and even internal, customers regarding statutory liens and NFTLs. Caution: The term “lien” is often used generically by external and internal customers when referring to the NFTL. There is a distinct legal between a statutory lien and an NFTL, so care should be taken to there is no confusion about what is being referenced when “lien” is (
) Also, though it may seem obvious, it is important to understand that a lien NFTL is not a levy. Information about levies can be found in IRM
, of Levy, and IRM
, Seizure and Sale. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Taxpayer rights with regard to Internal Revenue Service processes are stipu- lated in IRC 7803(a)(3) and referenced throughout the IRM 5.12 sections.
) IRC
provides the IRS a powerful tool allowing the Government to protect the American taxpaying public’s interest in collecting the proper amount of tax revenues. This tool is the federal tax lien. (

) A federal tax lien is a claim against property, including current and future rights to property. It represents the tax or tax-related debt of an individual or business. Because the lien arises by operation of law, it is sometimes called the “statutory lien” or “assessment lien.” Throughout this IRM Chapter, it will be referred to as the statutory lien or simply “lien.” (

) While the Service makes the taxpayer aware of the existence of the lien, it does not make the lien’s existence public until a notice of the lien has been ﬁled. The IRS puts third parties on notice of a taxpayer’s outstanding lien by ﬁling a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) in the appropriate, local recording office. (
) There are some common misunderstandings among external, and even internal, customers regarding statutory liens and NFTLs.

A federal tax lien is a claim against property, including current and future rights to property. It represents the tax or tax-related debt of an individual or business. Because the lien arises by operation of law, it is sometimes called the “statutory lien” or “assessment lien.” Throughout this IRM Chapter, it will be referred to as the statutory lien or simply “lien.”

The term “lien” is often used generically by external and internal customers when referring to the NFTL. There is a distinct legal difference between a statutory lien and an NFTL, so care should be taken to there is no confusion about what is being referenced when “lien” is used.
Federal Tax (
) A Federal Tax Lien is created by the statute IRC

, which is why it is to be created by operation of law. The following must occur for the and Duration lien to arise: • An assessment must have been made; • Notice and demand for payment must have been made; and • The taxpayer must have neglected or refused to pay. (
) The statutory lien attaches to a taxpayer’s current and future property and rights to property for the amount of the liability. (
) Pursuant to IRC
, the lien is effective from the assessment date and continues to exist until the liability is satisﬁed or becomes unenforceable by lapse of time. (
) The NFTL is a public notiﬁcation ﬁled with an office designated by state local jurisdictions. and Effect of (

) The purpose of ﬁling the NFTL publicly is to both: a Notice of Tax Lien. • inform certain third parties (typically a purchaser, holder of a security interest, mechanic’s lienor, or judgment lien creditor) of the the statutory lien securing the tax debt, and • establish the Government’s right of priority against these same (
) NFTLs are ﬁled under provision of IRC
) The NFTL is to be used only in accordance with the guidance found in IRM
, Federal Tax Liens, and related IRM chapters. Reminder: Estate and Gift Tax Liens are discussed in IRM
, and Judicial Actions for Estate Taxes. (
) For additional information about NFTLs, see IRM
, Federal Tax (

) Generally, lien priorities are determined by ″the ﬁrst in time, ﬁrst in right″ Under that rule, the Service relies on the date of assessment, which is the and NFTL Priorities date the lien arises. However, IRC
provides deviations from the rule. • For some classes of creditors, the federal tax lien will not have until the NFTL is ﬁled. See IRC
(a). • For other classes of creditors, the federal tax lien does not have even if an NFTL has been ﬁled. These are called the See IRC
) Lien priorities are fully explained in IRM
, Federal Tax Liens. (

) Because other creditors become aware of the outstanding tax debt through NFTL ﬁling, the NFTL may impact the taxpayer’s credit rating or their ability Effect on get credit (such as a loan, credit card, or lease). That is why it is so Credit that taxpayers resolve liabilities as quickly as possible, before an NFTL becomes necessary.

, the lien is effective from the assessment date and continues to exist until the liability is satisﬁed or becomes unenforceable lapse of time. (

For additional information about NFTLs, see IRM 5.17.2, Federal Tax Liens.

Because other creditors become aware of the outstanding tax debt through the NFTL ﬁling, the NFTL may impact the taxpayer’s credit rating or their ability to get credit (such as a loan, credit card, or lease). That is why it is so important that taxpayers resolve liabilities as quickly as possible, before an NFTL ﬁling becomes necessary.

) The majority of NFTLs are ﬁled at the request of Field Collection and Some NFTL ﬁling is also performed by Accounts Management working tion issues. These units also assist taxpayers with addressing lien rely on Counsel, as needed, to fulﬁll their responsibilities. (
) Appeals and TAS can also intervene with resolving lien issues. (
) The IRS Office of Appeals handles formal appeals through either Due Process (CDP) or the Collection Appeals Program (CAP). See IRM
, Appeals Processes Involving Liens, for speciﬁc lien program instructions or see IRM
Collection Appeal Rights, for general appeal instructions. (
) The Appeals IRMs on CDP and CAP procedures for NFTL ﬁlings are Collection Due Process, and IRM
, Collection Appeals Program and Jeopardy Levy Appeals.

The majority of NFTLs are ﬁled at the request of Field Collection and ACS. Some NFTL ﬁling is also performed by Accounts Management working collec- tion issues. These units also assist taxpayers with addressing lien issues and rely on Counsel, as needed, to fulﬁll their responsibilities.

5.12.1.5.2 (07-11-2018) Taxpayer Advocate Service
Refer a taxpayer to TAS if they ask to be referred or they meet TAS criteria and their issue cannot be resolved the “same day” (within 24 hours).
If the issue can be resolved and closed within
hours of the TAS contact, do not refer the inquiry to TAS. If the issue cannot completely be resolved within
hours, but steps have been taken within
hours to resolve the issue, do not refer the case to TAS unless the taxpayer asks to be transferred. These cases also meet the deﬁnition of ″same day.″

5.12.1.10.1 (07-11-2018) Disclosure of Amount to Third Parties
real estate transaction of an unrelated taxpayer are considered third parties. (
) Authorized employees may disclose the amount of the outstanding obligation secured by the NFTL to a third party when one of the following is present: • Valid Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of (IRM
, General Requirements for Disclosure to Designee); • Valid Form
, Tax Information Authorization (IRM
, Authority Granted by Form
); • Telephonic authorization from the taxpayer (IRM
, Require- ments for Oral Authorization); or • A written request demonstrates a person or entity possesses, or to obtain, a right in property attached by the lien (IRM
, Dis- closure of Amount of Outstanding Lien). (

) Taxpayers may authorize disclosure telephonically. Verify the taxpayer’s identity using approved functional procedures and document the case history about the authorization, including the following: • The information to be disclosed (e.g., the amount of the NFTL, the address of the property subject to the lien); • The identity of the third party authorized to receive the information; • The date of the consent. Example: On
, Taxpayer A verbally authorized disclosure of the payoff amount of all NFTLs to XYZ Title for the sale of property at
Maple Boulevard. (

) Any person, other than the taxpayer or their designee, desiring information to the amount of the outstanding obligation in order to decide whether to acquire the property covered by the lien (when an NFTL has been ﬁled) submit a written request stating the reason(s) the information is needed and properly identifying the NFTL in question. Also, a prospective purchaser attach a copy of the sales contract or a lender loan application. (

) Disclose information only for the tax liabilities included in the authorization. formation about liabilities not on an NFTL should not be disclosed to a third party without obtaining the taxpayer’s authorization, either orally or in writing. Document taxpayer authorizations in the case history. Internal Revenue Manual
Authorized employees may disclose the amount of the outstanding obligation secured by the NFTL to a third party when one of the following is present:
• Valid Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative (IRM
, General Requirements for Disclosure to Designee); • Valid Form
, Tax Information Authorization (IRM
, Authority Granted by Form
); • Telephonic authorization from the taxpayer (IRM
, Require- ments for Oral Authorization); or • A written request demonstrates a person or entity possesses, or intends to obtain, a right in property attached by the lien (IRM
, Dis- closure of Amount of Outstanding Lien).

) Any person, other than the taxpayer or their designee, desiring information as to the amount of the outstanding obligation in order to decide whether to acquire the property covered by the lien (when an NFTL has been ﬁled) must submit a written request stating the reason(s) the information is needed and properly identifying the NFTL in question. Also, a prospective purchaser attach a copy of the sales contract or a lender loan application. (

) Disclose information only for the tax liabilities included in the authorization. In- formation about liabilities not on an NFTL should not be disclosed to a third party without obtaining the taxpayer’s authorization, either orally or in writing.

) Seek advice from Area Counsel in situations where the taxpayer’s tion cannot be obtained (e.g., taxpayer is medically incapacitated, taxpayer on vacation outside the U.S. and cannot be reached, etc.).

) The Centralized Lien Operation (CLO) holds the primary responsibility for cessing NFTL documents. CLO’s duties include the following: • Creating and maintaining NFTLs on ALS and processing documents generated by ALS. • Interacting with recording offices throughout the United States and its territories to ﬁle lien documents and facilitate payment of applicable recording fees. • Administering the ALS database, including but not limited to, adding removing users, resolving exception reports, providing assistance to other functional users. • Assisting IRS employees regarding non-technical ALS issues. (
) Most new NFTLs are requested, and most releases generated, through ALS’ systemic interfaces. When manually requesting an NFTL or other NFTL document, complete the appropriate request form (see IRM
, NFTLs and Certiﬁcates). Forward the form to CLO via secure email or efax. Note: Contact information for CLO can be found on SERP under the Who/Where tab (Liens-Centralized Lien Processing). (
) If CLO encounters a problem with a request, they may contact the employee. Occasionally, CLO will need to refer an issue to their Field Office Resource Team (FORT). (

) If a Collection employee encounters a problem with an NFTL document, they should contact CLO. After researching the matter, CLO will advise the employee of how to resolve the problem, which could include correcting the
The Centralized Lien Operation (CLO) holds the primary responsibility for pro- cessing NFTL documents. CLO’s duties include the following:
Creating and maintaining NFTLs on ALS and processing documents generated by ALS.
Interacting with recording offices throughout the United States and its territories to ﬁle lien documents and facilitate payment of applicable recording fees.
Administering the ALS database, including but not limited to, adding removing users, resolving exception reports, providing assistance to other functional users.
Assisting IRS employees regarding non
technical ALS issues. Most new NFTLs are requested, and most releases generated, through ALS’
Note: Contact information for CLO can be found on SERP under the Who/Where tab (Liens-Centralized Lien Processing).
) If CLO encounters a problem with a request, they may contact the requesting employee. Occasionally, CLO will need to refer an issue to their Field Office Resource Team (FORT). (

) If a Collection employee encounters a problem with an NFTL document, they should contact CLO. After researching the matter, CLO will advise the employee of how to resolve the problem, which could include correcting the
NFTL (see IRM
, NFTL Corrections). If the employee does not with CLO’s resolution or if the issue is a general problem impacting NFTL documents, the employee may contact the CLO FORT. (

) For assistance with the ALS database on changes such as POD group numbers, and county/zip code matches, the ﬁeld employee contact the local ICS IQ Analyst who will coordinate the changes with Functional Coordinator. (
) For more information about CLO processing, communication, and control responsibilities, see IRM
, Centralized Lien Operation. (
) The FORT is CLO’s technical resource for NFTL issues, ALS elevated recording situations. A staff revenue officer/advisor is available assist with more complex issues. (
) Referrals to the FORT generally come from the CLO teams, but they come from recording offices, ﬁeld employees, and other internal or sources. (

) FORT responsibilities may include, but are not limited to, the following: • Technical questions regarding lien document requests • Reviews of lien documents not processed through ALS • Procedural issues involving NFTLs and lien certiﬁcates • Controls for estate tax lien ﬁlings • Work stoppages due to recording office rejections or billing • Updates to ALS support tables (
) As needed, the FORT works with Headquarters Analysts, Liaisons, and Counsel to address issues beyond their control. (
) For more information about the FORT, see IRM
, Field Office Resource Team (FORT). (

) ALS electronically stores data regarding NFTL ﬁlings and generates documents. ALS provides the tools for users to: System • create, amend, reﬁle, and withdraw NFTLs; • release liens and revoke releases; • process NFTL notiﬁcation letters; and • print NFTL and CDP letter facsimiles. (

) ALS interfaces with many IRS systems, including the following: • ACS and ICS - for systemic NFTL requests • Master File - to upload transaction codes related to NFTL ﬁlings • Correspondence Production Services (CPS) - to print and mail notices (
) Any employee with a business need can request research access to (

) The Coordinator also assists with ALS secondary passwords for those with advanced permissions in ALS. Note: The ALS Coordinator can only reset the ALS secondary password. UNIX login passwords (i.e., the initial logon password) are reset through the IT Help Desk. (
) For changes to POD addresses, group numbers, or county/zip code in ALS, contact the local IQA, who will coordinate the changes with the ALS Coordinator. (
) ALS Coordinator information can be found through the CLO Contact Page the ALS web page. (

) ALS access requests must include the employee’s IDRS TSIGN number. Employees cannot be added to ALS without a TSIGN. ALS uses the TSIGN number to associate lien requestor, and approver, information with lien documents. Therefore, ALS access requests cannot be processed unless employee’s TSIGN is provided. Note: If the employee does not have a TSIGN, the functional manager must and provide one. See ADP Handbook, Section
, Collection, for ALS programmers and Compliance Policy staff do not provide TSIGNs for ALS use. The ALS Coordinator can assist functional managers, if needed. (

) CLO is the contact point for recording officials with questions about NFTL documents or concerns about the lien process. Recording offices are Recording CLO contact information with the lien documents presented for ﬁling and Pub
, Guidelines for Processing Notice of Federal Tax Lien (

) Upon receiving an inquiry, CLO investigates the situation, explains the position, and takes necessary steps to resolve the issue. As needed, CLO contact Policy Analysts, Counsel, ALS staff, or other impacted offices. (

) Field employees’ contact with recording officials is generally limited to record searches or situations where an NFTL has to be manually ﬁled. sionally though, a recording official might contact a ﬁeld employee lien document or ﬁling question. The employee should respond with the priate information, if possible, or direct the recording official to CLO. In situation, the employee should inform CLO of the inquiry as CLO is in the position to recognize if the concern is a one-time situation or if there are multiple recording offices with concerns on the same topic. (

) Recording offices normally charge a fee to record documents presented ﬁling. The amount charged varies by recording office and the type of document. CLO maintains information in ALS about the amounts charged each recording office. (

) When CLO processes NFTL documents for ﬁling, CLO builds a Billing Voucher (BSV) for all the documents to be ﬁled in that recording office and ALS calculates the total ﬁling fee to be paid. After mailing the batch of documents for ﬁling, CLO enters payment certiﬁcation into ALS, which an electronic payment to the recording office through the Integrated System (IFS). See IRM
, Billing Support Voucher, for further mation.
The ALS Coordinator is responsible for updates to user proﬁles. Passwords are generally responded to within three (3) days of request receipt.

document. CLO maintains information in ALS about the amounts charged by each recording office. ) All NFTL documents, including manually-prepared ones, should be ﬁled through CLO so that they can be included in the BSV payment process. In rare situation where exigent circumstances exist and the NFTL document be hand-carried to the recording office for ﬁling, the employee presenting document to the recording office is responsible for ensuring the ﬁling fee is paid. See IRM
, Hand-Carried NFTL for Filing, for detailed proce- dures. (

) Lien-related certiﬁcates, such as those for discharge, subordination, and attachment, are not ﬁled by IRS, but are issued directly to the taxpayer or a third party. It is the responsibility of the taxpayer or third party that presents certiﬁcate for ﬁling to pay any fees charged by the recording office. (

) An NFTL is requested, either systemically or manually, and generated on • Most NFTLs are requested systemically through ICS and ACS. ALS terfaces with these systems on a nightly basis and generates the the following day. Note: ACS requests are subject to a perfection process before being loaded to ALS. The NFTL will not be generated on ALS until request is perfected. See IRM

, Perfecting Entity Name/TIN Before NFTL Filing. • An NFTL can be manually requested and the NFTL information input to ALS. Generally, this is done for cases not assigned on ICS or ACS, or for NFTLs requiring special wording (e.g., special condition NFTLs). ALS generates manually-input NFTLs the same day. • In rare situations, Field Collection may manually prepare an NFTL by completing Form
(Y). The NFTL information must still be input to ALS directly or through the manual ICS NFTL process. See IRM
, Manually-Prepared NFTLs Using ICS. (

) If applicable, Power of Attorney (POA) information for the NFTL is loaded to ALS. • For systemic NFTL requests, ICS and ACS pass available POA tion to ALS with the request. • For manual requests and for systemic requests where POA is not on ICS/ACS, POA information must be manually input to ALS. See IRM
, Requesting NFTLs Using Form
, and IRM
, Notifying the Authorized Representative/Power of (
) After the NFTL is generated on ALS, it is printed by CLO in the next print cycle, which is normally within ﬁve (
) business days. See IRM
, Printing the NFTL. (
) CLO batches the printed NFTL with other lien documents on a Billing Voucher (BSV) and mails the batched documents to the applicable office the day after being printed. See IRM
, Printing and Mailing Documents for Recordation. (

Amended and reﬁled NFTLs are manually input to ALS and generally follow the same process described above. TC 582s are posted for these ﬁlings and, if applicable, TCs 360 and 971 AC 252 are also posted. See IRM 5.12.7.9.2, Correcting the Filed NFTL, and IRM 5.12.8, Notice of Lien Reﬁling.
Master File generally updates its systems during the ﬁrst two to three cycles of the calendar year. This period is known as the “dead cycles.”
release process. Irrespective of the dead cycles, certiﬁcates of release must be issued within the 30-day time frame established by IRC 6325(a).
While working a case, if the liability(s) on the NFTL is fully satisﬁed during the dead cycles, a certiﬁcate of release should be manually requested through ALS. See IRM
, Lien Release Conditions.

Payments that are received, or other satisfying transactions that at the end of the calendar year may have their posting to Master File delayed by the dead cycles. Releases should be manually requested for any satisfying transactions impacted by the dead cycles.
Transaction codes for lien documents processed during the dead cycles will post when Master File is back on line.

ALS access options have been established for employees in the following functions, including affiliated revenue officers, specialists, tax examiners, case workers, clerks, and group secretaries. Permissions must be approved by managers and may be altered to meet speciﬁc employee needs.

Field TAS, Advisory, Permission MOIC COIC CIO Collection Appeals Insolvency Research x x x x x x Print Facsimiles x x x x x x Create x x x Edit x Amend x Reﬁle x x Input POA x x x x Court Data x Withdrawal x x Release x x x Partial Release x x Revocation x x Add History x x x Approve x y x x
x = standard permission; y = for managers only; z = requires managerial approval
